turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Don't I know you two from somewhere?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: We're just a couple of musicians - we come to pick up a car - Nellie Weinmeyer's car - there's a dance tonight -  Come on, Jerry.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Wait a minute.  Where do you think you're going?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: To Urbana.  It's a hundred miles.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: You ain't going nowhere.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: I don't like no witnesses.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: We won't breathe a word.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: You won't breathe nothing' - not even air.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: I don't mean to be forward - but ain't I had the pleasure of meeting you two broads before?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Oh, no!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Anything today?

turns.speaker: NELLIE
turns.text: Oh, it's you!  You got a lot of nerve -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Now look, Nellie - if it's about last Saturday night - I can explain everything.

turns.speaker: NELLIE
turns.text: What a heel!  I spend four dollars to get my hair marcelled, I buy me a new negligee, I bake him a great big pizza pie...  - and where were you?

turns.speaker: NELLIE
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Nellie baby, I'll make it up to you.

turns.speaker: NELLIE
turns.text: You're making it up pretty good so far.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: The minute we get a job, I'm going to take you out to the swellest restaurant -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What's the job?

turns.speaker: NELLIE
turns.text: It's three weeks in Florida -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Please, Jerry - that's no way to talk.  Nellie baby - what are you doing tonight?

turns.speaker: NELLIE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Because I got some plans -

turns.speaker: NELLIE
turns.text: I'm not doing anything.  I just thought I'd go home and have some cold pizza -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: And you'll be in all evening?

turns.speaker: NELLIE
turns.text: Yes, Joe.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Good!  Then you won't be needing your car.

turns.speaker: NELLIE
turns.text: My car?  Why, you -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Hey, Sig - can we talk to you?

turns.speaker: POLIAKOFF
turns.text: Nellie, get me long distance.  What is it?

turns.speaker: POLIAKOFF
turns.text: What are you - a couple of comedians? Get out of here!  Long distance?  Get me the William Morris Agency in New York.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You need a bass and a sax, don't you?

turns.speaker: POLIAKOFF
turns.text: The instruments are right, but you are not.  I want to speak to Mr. Morris.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: The wrong shape?  You looking for hunchbacks or something?

turns.speaker: POLIAKOFF
turns.text: It's not the backs that worry me.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What kind of band is this, anyway?

turns.speaker: POLIAKOFF
turns.text: You got to be under twenty-five -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: No, we couldn't!

turns.speaker: POLIAKOFF
turns.text: William Morris!

turns.speaker: POLIAKOFF
turns.text: Look, if you boys want to pick up a little money tonight -  At the University of Illinois they are having - you should excuse the expression - a St. Valentine's dance.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: We'll take it!

turns.speaker: POLIAKOFF
turns.text: You got it.  It's six dollars a man.  Be on the campus in Urbana at eight o'clock -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Well, here we are.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: You two from the Poliakoff Agency?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Yes, we're the new girls.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: Hey, Sheboygan - you two - what was your last job - playing square dances?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: No - funerals.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: Would you mind rejoining the living? Goose it up a little.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: We got it second-hand.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: All right - lets take it from the top. And put a little heat under it, will you?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: We got time off for good behavior.

turns.speaker: SUE
turns.text: There are two things I will not put up with during working hours.  One is liquor - and the other one is men.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Tell what?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: If they catch me once more, they'll boot me out of the band.  You the replacement for the bass and the sax?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Yes.  I come from a very musical family. My mother is a piano teacher and my father was a conductor.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Where did he conduct?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: On the Baltimore and Ohio.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I play the ukulele.  And I sing too.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Running away?  From what?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Don't get me started on that.  Want a drink?  It's bourbon.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: We understand.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: All the girls drink - but I'm the one that gets caught.  That's the story of my life. I always get the fuzzy end of the lollipop.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Put it here.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Sugar, you're going to get yourself into a lot of trouble.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Better keep a lookout.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: If Bienstock catches you again - What's the matter with you, anyway?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I'm not very bright, I guess.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I wouldn't say that.  Careless, maybe.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: No, just dumb.  If I had any brains, I wouldn't be on this crummy train with this crummy girls' band.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Then why did you take this job?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I used to sing with male bands. But I can't afford it any more.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Afford it?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Have you ever been with a male band?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Me?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: That's what I'm running away from. I worked with six different ones in the last two years.  Oh, brother!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Rough?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I'll say.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You can't trust those guys.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I can't trust myself.  The moment I'd start with a new band - bingo!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Bingo?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: You see, I have this thing about saxophone players.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Especially tenor sax.  I don't know what it is, but they just curdle me.  All they have to do is play eight bars of "Come to Me My Melancholy Baby" - and my spine turns to custard, and I get goose-pimply all over - and I come to them.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: That so?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Every time!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You know - I play tenor sax.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: But you're a girl, thank goodness.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: That's why I joined this band. Safety first.  Anything to get away from those bums.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: You don't know what they're like. You fall for them and you love 'em - you think it's going to be the biggest thing since the Graf Zeppelin - and the next thing you know they're borrowing money from you and spending it on other dames and betting on the horses -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You don't say?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Then one morning you wake up and the saxophone is gone and the guy is gone, and all that's left behind is a pair of old socks and a tube of toothpaste, all squeezed out.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Men!

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: So you pull yourself together and you go on to the next job, and the next saxophone player, and it's the same thing all over again.  See what I mean? - not very bright.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Brains aren't everything.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I can tell you one thing - it's not going to happen to me again.  Ever. I'm tired of getting the fuzzy end of the lollipop.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: You know I'm going to be twenty-five in June?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You are?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: That's a quarter of a century. Makes a girl think.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: About what?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: About the future.  You know - like a husband?  That's why I'm glad we're going to Florida.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What's in Florida?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Millionaires.  Flocks of them.  They all go south for the winter.  Like birds.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Going to catch yourself a rich bird?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Oh, I don't care how rich he is - as long as he has a yacht and his own private railroad car and his own toothpaste.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You're entitled.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Maybe you'll meet one too, Josephine.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Yeah.  With money like Rockefeller, and shoulders like Johnny Weismuller -

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I want mine to wear glasses.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Glasses?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Men who wear glasses are so much more gentle and sweet and helpless. Haven't you ever noticed?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Well, now that you've mentioned it -

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: They get those weak eyes from reading - you know, all those long columns of tiny figures in the Wall Street Journal.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Happy days.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I hope this time you wind up with the sweet end of the lollipop.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: What's happened?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Search me.  I mean - I'll see.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Okay, Sugar - all clear.  You better go back to bed.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I might as well stay in there. I won't be able to sleep anyway.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Bienstock.  He snores to beat the band. We cut cards to see who sleeps over him, and I always lose.  Wouldn't you know?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Want to switch berths with me?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Would you mind terribly?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Not at all.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Thanks, honey.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Good night, Sugar.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Well, there they are - more millionaires than you can shake a stick at.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I'll bet there isn't one of them under seventy-five.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Seventy-five.  That's three-quarters of a century.  Makes a girl think.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I wish they'd put us in the same room.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: So do I.  But don't worry - we'll be seeing a lot of each other.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: 414 - that's the same room number I had in Cincinnati - my last time around with a male band. What a heel he was.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Saxophone player?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: What else?  And was I ever crazy about him. Two in the morning, he sent me down for knackwurst and potato salad - they were out of potato salad, so I brought coleslaw - so he threw it right in my face.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Forget it, Sugar, will you?  Forget about saxophone players.  You're going to meet a millionaire - a young one.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: What makes you so sure?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Just my feminine intuition.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Wait a minute, Daphne.  You haven't got a bathing suit.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: She doesn't need one.  I don't have one either.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Oh, I'm terribly sorry.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: My fault.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You're not hurt, are you?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I wish you'd make sure.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Because usually, when people find out who I am, they get themselves a wheel chair and a shyster lawyer, and sue me for a quarter of a million dollars.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Well, don't worry.  I won't sue you - no matter who you are.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Now, really -

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Haven't I seen you somewhere before?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Not very likely.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Are you staying at the hotel?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Not at all.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Your face is familiar.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Possible you saw it in a newspaper - or magazine - Vanity Fair -

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: That must be it.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Would you mind moving just a little? You're blocking my view.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Your view of what?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: They run up a red-and-white flag on the yacht when it's time for cocktails.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: You have a yacht?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Which one is yours - the big one?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Certainly not.  with all that unrest in the world, I don't think anybody should have a yacht that sleeps more than twelve.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I quite agree.  Tell me, who runs up that flat - your wife?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: No, my flag steward.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: And who mixes the cocktails - your wife?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: No, my cocktail steward.  Look, if you're interested in whether I'm married or not -

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I'm not interested at all.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Well, I'm not.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: That's very interesting.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: How's the stock market?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Up, up, up.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I'll bet just while we were talking, you made like a hundred thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Could be.  Do you play the market?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: No - the ukulele.  And I sing.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: For your own amusement?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Well - a group of us are appearing at the hotel. Sweet Sue and Her Society Syncopators.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You're society girls?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Oh, yes.  Quite.  You know - Vassar, Bryn Mawr - we're only doing this for a lark.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Syncopators - does that mean you play that fast music - jazz?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Yeah.  Real hot.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Oh.  Well, I guess some like it hot.  But personally, I prefer classical music.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: So do I.  as a matter of fact, I spent three years at the Sheboygan Conservatory of Music.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Good school!  And your family doesn't object to your career?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: They do indeed.  Daddy threatened to cut me off without a cent, but I don't care. It was such a bore - coming-out parties, cotillions -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: - Inauguration balls -

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: - opening of the Opera -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: - riding to hounds -

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: - and always the same Four Hundred.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You know, it's amazing we never ran into each other before.  I'm sure I would have remembered anybody as attractive as you.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: You're very kind.  I'll bet you're also very gentle - and helpless -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I beg your pardon?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: You see, I have this theory about men with glasses.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What theory?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Maybe I'll tell you when I know you a little better.  What are you doing tonight?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Tonight?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I thought you might like to come to the hotel and hear us play.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I'd like to - but it may be rather difficult.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I only come ashore twice a day - when the tide goes out.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: It's on the account of the shells. That's my hobby.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: You collect shells?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Yes.  So did my father and my grandfather - we've all had this passion for shells - that's why we named the oil company after it.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Shell Oil?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Please - no names.  Just call me Junior.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Would you mind moving along, please?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Yes, you're in the way.  He's waiting for a signal from his yacht.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Well, I guess I'd better go -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: It's been delightful meeting you both.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: And you will come to hear us tonight?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: If it's at all possible -

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Josephine.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Oh, I didn't hear you come in.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: The most wonderful thing happened -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Guess!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: They repealed Prohibition?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: One of whom?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Shell Oil, Junior.  He's got millions - he's got glasses - and he's got a yacht.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You don't say!

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Well, he's young and handsome and a bachelor - and he's a real gentleman - not one of these grabbers.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Maybe you'd better go after him - if you don't want to lose him.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Oh, I'm not going to let this one get away. He's so cute - collects shells.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Shells?  Whatever for?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Anyway, you're going to meet him tonight.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I am?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Because he said he's coming to hear us play - maybe.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I guess he's not going to show up - it's give minutes to one - you suppose he forgot?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Well, you know how those millionaires are.  These came for you.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: For me?  It's Shell Oil.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You heard her - yes.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Oh, Josephine - just imagine - me, Sugar Kowalczyk, from Sandusky, Ohio, on a millionaire's yacht.  If my mother could only see me now -

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Been waiting long?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: It's not how long you wait - it's who you're waiting for.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Thank you.  And thank you for the flowers.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I wanted them to fly down some orchids from our greenhouse but all of Long Island is fogged in.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: It's the thought that counts.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I seem to be out of gas.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: It's sort of funny - you being out of gas - I mean, Shell Oil and everything -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I just got this motorboat - it's an experimental model.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Looks like they're on the wrong track.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Do you mind riding backwards? It may take a little longer -

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: It's not how long it takes - it's who's taking you.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: It looked so small from the beach - but when you're on it, it's more like a cruiser - or a destroyer.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Just regulation size.  We have three like this.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Three?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Mother keeps hers in Southampton - and Dad took his to Venezuela - the company is laying a new pipe line.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: My dad is more interested in railroads. Baltimore and Ohio.  Which is the port and which is the starboard?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Well, that depends - on whether you're coming or going - I mean, normally the aft is on the other side of the stern - and that's the bridge - so you can get from one side of the boat to the other - how about a glass of champagne?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Love it.  Which way?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Yes - now let's see - where do you suppose the steward set it up?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Oh, you have an upstairs and a downstairs.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Yes - that's our hurricane cellar.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Oh - in here.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Of course.  On Thursdays, they always serve me in the small salon.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: It's exquisite - like a floating mansion.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: It's all right for a bachelor.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: What a beautiful fish.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Caught him off Cape Hatteras.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Oh - a member of the herring family.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: A herring?  Isn't it amazing how they get those big fish into those little glass jars?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: They shrink when they're marinated.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Champagne?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I don't mind if I do.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Down the hatch - as we say at sea.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Bon voyage.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Look at all that silverware.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Trophies.  You know - skeet-shooing, dog-breeding, water polo...

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Water polo - isn't that terribly dangerous?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I'll say.  I had two ponies drowned under me.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Where's your shell collection?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Yea, of course.  Now where could they have put it?  On Thursdays, I'm sort of lost around here.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: What's on Thursdays?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: It's the crews' night off.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: You mean we're alone on the boat?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Completely.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: You know, I've never been completely alone with a man before - in the middle of the night - in the middle of the ocean.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Oh, it's perfectly safe.  We're well anchored - the ship is in shipshape - and the Coast Guard promised to call me if there are any icebergs around.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: It's not the icebergs.  But there are certain men who would try to take advantage of a situation like this.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You're flattering me.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Well, of course, I'm sure you're a gentleman.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Oh, it's not that. It's just that I'm - harmless.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Harmless - how?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Well, I don't know how to put it - but I have this thing about girls.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: What thing?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: They just sort of leave me cold.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: You mean - like frigid?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: It's more like a mental block.  When I'm with girls, it does nothing to me.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Have you tried?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Have I?  I'm trying all the time.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: See?  Nothing.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Nothing at all?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Complete washout.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: That makes me feel just awful.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Oh, it's not your fault.  It's just that every now and then Mother Nature throws somebody a dirty curve.  Something goes wrong inside.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: You mean you can't fall in love?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Not anymore.  I was in love once - but I'd rather not talk about it.  How about a little cold pheasant?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I don't want to bore you.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Oh, you couldn't possibly.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Well, it was my freshman year at Princeton - there was this girl - her name was Nellie - her father was vice-president of Hupmobile - she wore glasses, too.  That summer we spent our vacation at the Grand Canyon - we were standing on the highest ledge, watching the sunset - suddenly we had an impulse to kiss - I took off my glasses - I took a step toward her - she took a step toward me -

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Oh, no!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Yes.  Eight hours later they brought her up by mule - I gave her three transfusions - we had the same blood type - Type O - it was too late.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Talk about sad.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Ever since then -  numb - no feelings.  Like my heart was shot full of novocaine.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: You poor, poor boy.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Yes - all the money in the world - but what good is it?  Mint sauce or cranberries?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: How can you think about food at a time like this?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What else is there for me?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Is it that hopeless?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: My family did everything they could - hired the most beautiful French upstairs maids - got a special tutor to read me all the books that were banned in Boston - imported a whole troupe of Balinese dancers with bells on their ankles and those long fingernails - what a waste of money!

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Have you ever tried American girls?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Is that anything?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Thanks just the same.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Maybe if you saw a good doctor...

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I have.  Spent six months in Vienna with Professor Freud - flat on my back -  - then there were the Mayo Brothers - and injections and hypnosis and mineral baths - if I weren't such a coward, I'd kill myself.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Don't talk like that.  I'm sure there must be some girl some place that could -

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: If I ever found a girl that could - I'd marry her like that.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Would you do me a favor?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I may not be Dr. Freud or a Mayo Brother or one of those French upstairs girls - but could I take another crack at it?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: All right - if you insist.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Anything this time?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I'm afraid not.  Terribly sorry.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Would you like a little more champagne?  And maybe if we had some music -  - how do you dim these lights?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Look, it's terribly sweet of you to want to help out - but it's no use.  I think the light switch is over there -  - and that's the radio.  It's like taking somebody to a concert when he's tone deaf.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: You're not giving yourself a chance. Don't fight it.  Relax.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: It's like smoking without inhaling.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: So inhale!

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Well - ?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I'm not quite sure.  Try it again.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I got a funny sensation in my toes - like somebody was barbecuing them over a slow flame.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Lets throw another log on the fire.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I think you're on the right track.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I must be - because your glasses are beginning to steam up.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I never knew it could be like this.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: They told me I was caputt - finished - washed up - and now you're making a chump out of all those experts.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Mineral baths - now really!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Where did you learn to kiss like that?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Oh, you know - Junior League - charity bazaars - I used to sell kisses for the Milk Fund.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Good night.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Good morning.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: How much do I owe the Milk Fund so far?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Eight hundred and fifty thousand dollars.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Let's make it an even million.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Oh, no.  I'm off that stuff - for good.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Did you have a nice time?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Nice?  It was suicidally beautiful.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Gee, I wish I'd been there.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I'm going to see him again tonight - and every night - I think he's going to propose to me - as soon as he gets up his nerve.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: From a rich millionaire.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: That's wonderful.  Poor Josephine.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Me?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Daphne has a beau - I have a beau - if we could only find somebody for you.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: That's funny - I never slept better.  And I had the most wonderful dream.  I was still on the yacht, and the anchor broke loose - and we drifted for days and days - you were the captain and I was the crew - I kept a lookout for icebergs, and I sorted your shells, and mixed your cocktails, and wiped the steam off your glasses - and when I woke up, I felt like swimming right back to you.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Yes.  Now about our date for tonight...

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I'll meet you on the pier again - right after the show.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I'm afraid not.  I can't make it tonight.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Tomorrow night?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Not tomorrow, either.  You see, I have to leave - something unexpected came up - I'm sailing right away.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Where to?  South America?  Oh. That is unexpected.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You see, we have those oil interests in Venezuela - and I just got a cable from Dad - the board of directors decided on a merger.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: A merger?  How long will you be gone?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Quite a while.  As a matter of fact, I'm not coming back at all.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: You're not?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: It's all rather complicated - what we call high finance - but it so happens that the president of the Venezuelan syndicate has a daughter, and -

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Oh - that kind of a merger.  Is she young? Pretty?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: According to our tax advisers, she's only so-so.  But - that's the way the oil gushes. A man in my position has a certain responsibility to the stockholders - all those little people who invest their life savings -

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Oh, of course.  I understand.  At least, I think I do.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I knew you would.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: I only wish there were something I could do for you.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: But you have.  You've given me all that inside information - first thing tomorrow I'm going to call my broker and have him buy fifty thousand shares of Venezuelan oil.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Smart move.  Oh, by the way - did you get my flowers? You know, those orchids from my greenhouse - the fog finally lifted over Long Island, and they flew them down this morning.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Yes, they're here.  Oh - white orchids.  Would you believe it - I haven't had white orchids since I was a debutante.  What's this?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What's what?  Oh, that.  just a little going away present.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Real diamonds.  They must be worth their weight in gold.  Are you always this generous?

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Not always.  But I want you to know I'm very grateful for what you did for me.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I didn't do anything.  It just happened.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Oh.  The navigator just came in - we're ready to cast off.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: Well, anchors aweigh, you have a bon voyage.  And if you need an orchestra to play at your wedding, we'll be through here in a couple of weeks.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Goodbye, my darling.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: What's the matter, Sugar?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I don't know.  All of a sudden, I'm thirsty.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Daphne -

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: He was the first nice guy I ever met in my life - and the only one who ever gave me anything.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You'll forget him, Sugar.

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: How can I?  No matter where I go, there'll always be a Shell station on the corner.  I'll bring this back when it's empty.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Sugar!  What do you think you're doing?

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I told you - I'm not very bright.

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: You don't want me, Sugar - I'm a liar and a phony - a saxophone player - one of those no-goodnicks you've been running away from -

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: I know.  Every time!

turns.speaker: JOE
turns.text: Do yourself a favor - go back where the millionaires are - the sweet end of the lollipop - not the cole slaw in the face and the old socks and the squeezed-out tube of toothpaste -

turns.speaker: SUGAR
turns.text: That's right - pour it on.  Talk me out of it.

turns.speaker: MOZARELLA
turns.text: Good evening, sir.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: I come to the old lady's funeral.

turns.speaker: MOZARELLA
turns.text: I don't believe I've seen you at any of our services before.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: That's because I've been on the wagon.

turns.speaker: MOZARELLA
turns.text: PLEASE!

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Where are they holding the wake? I'm supposed to be one of the pallbearers.

turns.speaker: MOZARELLA
turns.text: Show the gentleman to the chapel - pew number three.

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: What'll it be, sir?

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Booze.

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: Sorry, sir, we only serve coffee.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Coffee?

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: Scotch coffee, Canadian coffee, sour-mash coffee...

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Make is Scotch.  A demitasse. With a little soda on the side.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Haven't you got another pew - not so close to the band?  How about that one?

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: Sorry, sir.  That's reserved for members of the immediate family.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Better bring the check now - in case the joint gets raided.

turns.speaker: WAITER
turns.text: Who's going to raid a funeral?

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Some people got no respect for the dead.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Okay, Spats - the services are over. Lets go.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Go where?

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: A little country club we run for retired bootleggers.  I'm gonna put your name up for membership.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: I never join nothin'.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: You'll like it there.  I'll have the prison tailor fit you with a pair of special spats - striped!

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Big joke.  Who's the rap this time?

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Embalming people with coffee - eighty-six proof.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Me?  I'm just a customer here.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Come on, Spats - we know you own this joint.  Mozarella is just fronting for you.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Mozarella?  Never heard of him.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: We got different information.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: From who?  Toothpick Charlie, maybe?

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Toothpick Charlie?  Never heard of him.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: You're wasting the taxpayers' money.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: If you want to, you can call your lawyer.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: These are my lawyers - all Harvard men.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Well, Spats Colombo - if I were saw one.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Hello, copper.  What brings you down to Florida?

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: I heard you opera-lovers were having a little rally - so I thought I better be around in case anybody decides to sing.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Big joke!

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Say, Maestro - where were you at three o'clock on St. Valentine's Day?

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Me?  I was at Rigoletto.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: What's his first name?  And where does he live?

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: That's an opera, you ignoramus.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Where did they play it - in a garage on Clark Street?

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Clark Street?  Never heard of it.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Ever hear of the DeLuxe French Cleaners on Wabash Avenue?

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Because the day after the shooting you sent in a pair of spats - they had blood on them.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: I cut myself shaving.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: You shave with your spats on?

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: I sleep with my spats on.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Quit kidding.  You did that vulcanizing job on Toothpick Charlie - and we know it.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: You and who else?

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Me and those two witnesses whom your lawyers have been looking for all over Chicago.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: You boys know anything about any garage - or any witnesses?

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: All right, Charlie - this the joint?

turns.speaker: TOOTHPICK CHARLIE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: And who runs it?

turns.speaker: TOOTHPICK CHARLIE
turns.text: I already told you.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Refresh my memory.

turns.speaker: TOOTHPICK CHARLIE
turns.text: Spats Colombo.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: That's very refreshing. Now what's the password?

turns.speaker: TOOTHPICK CHARLIE
turns.text: I come to Grandma's funeral.  Here's your admission card.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Thanks, Charlie.

turns.speaker: TOOTHPICK CHARLIE
turns.text: If you want a ringside table, tell 'em you're one of the pall bearers.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Okay, Charlie.

turns.speaker: TOOTHPICK CHARLIE
turns.text: Look, Chief - I better blow now, because if Spats Colombo sees me, it's Goodbye Charlie.

turns.speaker: MULLIGAN
turns.text: Goodbye, Charlie.

turns.speaker: PARADISE
turns.text: Hi, Spats.  We was laying eight to one you wouldn't show.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Why wouldn't I?

turns.speaker: PARADISE
turns.text: We thought you was all broken up about Toothpick Charlie.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Well, we all got to go sometime.

turns.speaker: PARADISE
turns.text: Yeah.  You never know who's going to be next.  Okay, Spats.  Report to the Sergeant- at-Arms.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: PARADISE
turns.text: Orders from Little Bonaparte.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Hello, Charlie.  Long time no see.

turns.speaker: TOOTHPICK CHARLIE
turns.text: What is it, Spats?  What do you want here?

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Just dropped in to pay my respects.

turns.speaker: TOOTHPICK CHARLIE
turns.text: You don't owe me no nothing.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Oh, I wouldn't say that.  You were nice enough to recommend my mortuary to some of your friends...

turns.speaker: TOOTHPICK CHARLIE
turns.text: I don't know what you're talking about.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: So now I got all those coffins on my hands - and I hate to see them go to waste.

turns.speaker: TOOTHPICK CHARLIE
turns.text: Honest, Spats.  I had nothing to do with it.

turns.speaker: SPATS
turns.text: Too bad, Charlie.  You would have had three eights.  Goodbye, Charlie!

turns.speaker: TOOTHPICK CHARLIE
turns.text: No, Spats - no, no, no -  NO!

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: You know what I love about all this?

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Theres finally a reason for the whole world to revolve around you?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Exactly! Todays my day. Tomorrow will be my day. And the day after that? My day.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Perfect. All ginny.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Except its Scotch.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: But Im not taking your name, buster. Im a feminist!  I need icey! Mr. husband-man, get me more icey!

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Did Kat tell you she dumped you because of your funky breath?

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Did Amy tell you she keeps her Homecoming tiara by the bed?

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Christ, Amy.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Oh, shut up and be happy. Its always this or that. Youre never happy, you frowny-faced Grumplestilskin.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Drunk isnt the same thing as happy, Amy.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Why dont you get my half sister her seventh hole?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Bacardi 151.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I dont think I can go through with this.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Pub Golf?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: The wedding.  I am so, so bad! I dont think I should be allowed to get married.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Do you want to come in for a minute? We could talk about--

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: When I freaked out at the pub?  That was nothing, just nerves. Dont worry about it.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: But I do. I will. Youre my sister.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: God, Kat! Please. Dont be nice to me. I can take anything right now but you being nice to me.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: What? Why? What do you mean?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: I should get going.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Are you sure youre okay?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Im fine. I promise.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: We were eating and puking together in harmony until one day, Tony walked me home from school. He was my first boyfriend.  I was fourteen.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: So Tony Pee-Pants starts ignoring Kat. He wanted to play with me.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: You practically bribed him with your erector set.
